awd_titl_txt: Animal disaggregases and amyloid based contributions to early animal development
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-Technical Abstract 

Enzymatic catalysts capable of disentangling potentially disease-causing protein aggregates have been proposed as a therapeutic solution to neurodegenerative disease. Given that all other forms of non-animal life already have these enzymes, it raises the question of why have humans lost the ability to express these potentially beneficial remedies? The answer to animal-specific loss of protein disentangling enzymes may lie in a potential beneficial role of protein aggregates that is incompatible with the presence of potent enzymes capable of destroying them. In this grant, the investigators will test this hypothesis in a comprehensive way by using the complementary features of two powerful genetic model organisms. Newly identified and potentially more subtle enzymatic regulators of protein aggregation will be identified using the yeast model system and then tested for regulation of the protein aggregates recently found in young, healthy embryos of the nematode worms. This grant will carry out a comprehensive examination of protein aggregates and their dedicated enzymatic regulators and seek to understand how they may serve as novel mechanisms to control key events in early animal development including the storage of key developmental proteins that can be released as required. To further connections between science and society, funds will also be used to develop new initiatives that expose middle school students, teachers and undergraduates to methods for studying genomes and genome evolution as well as the genetic analysis of complex traits.

Technical Abstract

Although processes of amyloid formation and inheritance are historically studied because of their associated pathologies, normal physiological roles of amyloid-type aggregates are becoming more appreciated with many examples of beneficial amyloid functions in species ranging from yeast to mammals. Interestingly, the potent Hsp100-type disaggregase, which plays a role in aggregate clearance, is absent in animal genomes. Thus, the central hypothesis of this grant is that broad-spectrum disaggregases like the Hsp100 class are incompatible with the evolution of animal multicellularity because protein aggregation and the maintenance of the amyloid form of specific proteins are required for animal development. Consistent with this, a surprising abundance of amyloid-type aggregates is shown during early development of C. elegans embryos. The objective of this grant is to characterize the role of amyloid aggregates during development and to investigate their regulation by identifying and characterizing developmentally expressed candidate animal disaggregases. To accomplish this objective, research plan capitalizes on complementary and synergistic experimental advantages of C. elegans and S. cerevisiae.  Experiments will 1) analyze the function and regulation of developmentally important amyloids by characterizing candidate endogenous animal disaggregase activities, 2) characterize key aggregation-prone proteins and their regulators in C. elegans development and 3) determine the function of C. elegans amyloidized protein aggregates.  Taken together, this grant will examine how amyloids and their dedicated disaggregases serve as novel regulators of key events in early animal development including storage, propagation and distribution of maternal and zygotically synthesized proteins.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

Amyloid protein aggregates are key features in pathogenesis associated with neurodegenerative diseases (e.g. Alzheimer’s, Parkinson’s, Huntington’s). Potent enzymes that process and even reverse amyloid formation encoded by fungal but not metazoan genomes have therapeutic potential, and introduction of the fungal Hsp104 enzyme into Drosophila and mammalian models shows promise for slowing amyloid-mediated neurodegeneration. If the Hsp104 class of amyloid processing enzymes is protective for animal health, then one fundamental question is: why is it lost from the genomes of animals? The answer may lie in the emerging appreciation of the many beneficial roles of amyloids. For example, in Aplysia and Drosophila, self-sustaining amyloids allow the maintenance of activity-dependent synaptic changes and the persistence of memory. Additionally, many mammalian peptide hormones (e.g. growth hormone, prolactin, ACTH, oxytocin and insulin) form amyloids in pituitary secretory vesicles, suggesting these amyloids normally serve a storage function. Considering the many functions associated with amyloids, it is not surprising that even after tuning expression, Hsp104 levels sufficient to suppress the effects of pathological amyloids caused collateral tissue damage presumably by mis-modulating normal amyloid-based developmental programs. These off-target effects suggest that Hsp104-like activity is too broad-spectrum to be tolerated in animals and suggest that client-specific amyloid processing enzymes might have evolved instead.  Based on preliminary data from our labs, we hypothesize that amyloids are an important part of animal developmental programs. To test this, we proposed to characterize the role of amyloid aggregates during early animal development and identify activities that contribute to their developmentally regulated formation and disaggregation.

Our initial focus was on the Abcf protein family, which has features similar to Hsp104 but is also present in animal genomes. In yeast, we found that the Abcf2 ortholog, Arb1, is involved in the resolubilization of disordered aggregates like denatured firefly luciferase, as well as in the processing of amyloid reporter genes including the Huntingtin protein, and endogenous aggregation-prone proteins like Sup35 and Rnq1. We found that animal ABCF genes rescue arb1 mutant aggregation phenotypes and that the ATPase enzymatic activity is important for ABCF aggregate processing functions. We found that Arb1 is physically associated with these aggregates suggesting a possible chaperone-client relationship. We also found an effect of Arb1 on P bodies, which are endogenous non-amyloid condensates implicated in stress responses, development and neurodegenerative disease.  Finally, semi-in vitro denatured luciferase assays identified certain categories of refolding chaperones are potential partners that might be required for Arb1 aggregate processing activity. In sum, our yeast work has identified a novel processing activity for amyloid and non-amyloid aggregates in both fungi and animals. 

Animal studies conducted in parallel suggest that this activity is developmentally important. Larval ABCF-1 depletion in C. elegans causes larval arrest while depletion in adults results in sterility due to an arrest of oogenesis. We further describe the accumulation of germline puncta positive for amyloid markers. Screening markers of candidate membraneless organelles shows these ABCF-regulated aggregates are positive for multiple P body markers but not other germline condensates, such as P granules. These data indicate that ABCF may be a client-specific regulator of protein condensation mechanisms, functioning to limit the size and number of specific membraneless organelles. Based on these results, we screened additional chaperones for novel membraneless organelle regulation and identified heat shock proteins (HSPs) that regulate, but incompletely overlap with, ABCF targets, suggesting distinct classes of chaperones may regulate specific clients, especially those involved with RNA metabolism.

Broader Impacts

In the Department of Biology, groups of high school students / prospective University of Iowa matriculants with an interest in biology and their families tour campus and visit the Biology complex. These families come from across the Midwest and tour the department in groups of ~5, creating an ideal situation for sparking conversations about the science in the department and its broader implications. However, guides for these tours are often non-scientists affiliated with admissions. We took advantage of a new program in the department in which senior undergraduate Biology majors lead the tour.  We directly train undergraduate ambassadors to help them communicate the complex science to diverse groups of visitors. Our 6-week Ambassador training program (ATP), helps the ambassadors develop communication tools including: 1) Interviewing skills to learn about the big picture science through conversations with a principal investigator; 2) Taking “research activity” photographs to document work being conducted by undergraduates;  3) Designing an easy-to-read & explain poster for each lab; and 4) Preparing an entertaining and educational “5-minute pitch” that brings each poster and the science in the department to life for tour attendees. We provided a monetary reward and certificate for ambassadors that completed the training and a small stipend for each enhanced tour they conducted. Over the course of this award, we have expanded the training class to 10 and have been able to reach over 500 visitors per year.
